DOCNAME: CASE OF N.A. AND OTHERS  v. TURKEY
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , ORG , PERSON , PERSON and ORG , were born in DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE .

CARDINAL . After surveys had been conducted by ORG DATE , a plot of land on the coast in the locality of GPE ( village of GPE , district of GPE , parcel no . CARDINAL ) was entered in the land register in the name of PERSON
CARDINAL . Following PERSON 's death , the applicants inherited the land and paid the appropriate taxes and duties on it .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants obtained a tourist investment certificate from ORG with a view to building a hotel on the land .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG awarded the applicants an investment incentive certificate , again for the purpose of building a hotel . Paragraph X of the certificate stated that the applicants had to obtain a tourism licence once the investment had been made .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after the applicants had started building the hotel , the ORG instituted proceedings in ORG , seeking an order for the cancellation of the entry of the property in the land register and for the demolition of the hotel .
CARDINAL . An expert report of DATE stated that parcel no . CARDINAL was part of the coastline and could not be the subject of an acquisition .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG made an interim order for the suspension of building work on the hotel .
CARDINAL . An expert report of CARDINAL DATE pointed out that parcel no . CARDINAL was part of the coastline and , as such , could not be owned by a private individual .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG ordered the cancellation of the entry in the land register and the demolition of the partially built hotel . It made the following observations :

“ [ Having regard to ] the expert report [ and ] ruling on the merits [ of the case ] , ... having regard to the available evidence and , in particular , the photographs and all the other items in the file , the ORG considers that the property in issue is part of the seashore [ LOC kıyısı ] . Although coastlines remain outside the boundary delimited and fixed in decisions by certain commissions , they can not constitute property that is subject to private ownership ... the registration of the property in the claimants ' name does not confer any rights on them . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed an appeal by the applicants against the interim order of DATE .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and remitted the case to the first - instance court .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , disregarding ORG judgment , ORG reaffirmed its initial ruling . It held :

“ ... the disputed site is the responsibility and property of the ORG . In that respect there is no discrepancy with [ the judgment ] delivered by ORG . Even the ORG , when placing restrictions on the enjoyment of possessions in accordance with property law ... , can not accept the existence of private property at such a site ... Although the property in issue in the present case was formerly situated within the coastal boundary , it was placed outside that boundary by [ a decision of ] the commission formed at DATE . The site was quite clearly located on a sandy beach , as , indeed , is apparent from previous judicial decisions that have become final , and from expert reports and photographs ... ”
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the judgment given by the lower court , finding it to have interpreted and applied the law correctly .
CARDINAL . In a judgment given on an unspecified date ORG confirmed its initial judgment .
CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the judgment given at first instance .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE it dismissed an application for rectification of the judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants brought an action for damages in the GPE ORG on account of their loss of ownership and the demolition of the partially built hotel .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG dismissed the applicants ' action on the ground that the ORG was not liable for the damage resulting from the cancellation of the registration of the property in issue . In its reasoning it stated that the applicants had asserted , on the basis of the entries in the land register , that they had made investments in relation to the land in question and that , as a result of the proceedings brought by the ORG for the cancellation of the registration , they had sustained a loss . ORG explained its decision by pointing out that the applicants and their heirs would have been aware that the site was on sandy ground , and that it was impossible for them to maintain that the ORG had deceived them and for the principle of strict liability to be applied in their case . It concluded that no loss had resulted from the contents of the land register , that the entry had been unlawful from the outset and that the applicants were accordingly not entitled to take proceedings against the ORG to seek compensation for the loss sustained .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the judgment given at first instance .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed an application for rectification of the judgment .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW provides :
“ The coasts are the property of the ORG and fall within its jurisdiction .
The public interest shall prevail in the use of seashores , lake shores and riverbanks and of the coastal strips situated by seas and lakes .
The law shall determine the width of coastal strips according to their use , together with the possibilities and conditions for such use by individuals . ”
